page.title: 02SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
page.content: Abington Hall, formerly owned by the Mortlocks, was taken over by the military during the Second World War. After the war it was bought by a research organisation to develop and investigate welding techniques. Originally, called the BWRA, it employed about ten people but now employs 550. The name was changed to The Welding Institute. The Institute has three main functions: welding research, communication, and engineering. The Institute is foremost in developing new techniques for welding modern structures including underwater welding, laser and electron beam welding, and the welding of plastics. Computers and sophisticated machines, especially microscopes are increasingly used to examine fractured metals.
